Afonso IV de Portugal - The Portuguese Genealogy (Genealogia dos Reis de Portugal).png | caption = Afonso in ''Genealogy of the Kings of Portugal'' (António de Holanda, 1530–1534) | reign = 7 January 1325{{snd}}28 May 1357 | predecessor = [[Denis, King of Portugal|Denis]] | successor = [[Peter I of Portugal|Peter I]] | spouse = [[Beatrice of Castile (1293–1359)|Beatrice of Castile]] | issue = [[Maria of Portugal, Queen of Castile|Maria]]
[[Peter I of Portugal|Peter]]
[[Eleanor of Portugal, Queen of Aragon|Eleanor]] | house = [[Portuguese House of Burgundy|Burgundy]] | father = [[Denis of Portugal]] | mother = [[Elizabeth of Aragon]] | birth_date = 8 February 1291 | birth_place = [[Lisbon]], [[Kingdom of Portugal]] | death_date = 28 May 1357 (aged 66) | death_place = [[Lisbon]], [[Kingdom of Portugal]] | burial_place = [[Lisbon Cathedral]], Portugal | religion = [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] }} '''Afonso IV'''English: ''Alphonzo'' or ''Alphonse'', or ''Affonso'' (Archaic Portuguese), ''Alfonso'' or ''Alphonso'' ([[Portuguese-Galician languages|Portuguese-Galician]]) or ''Alphonsus'' (Latin). ({{IPA-pt|ɐˈfõsu}}; 8 February 1291{{snd}}28 May 1357), called '''the Brave''' ({{lang-pt|o Bravo|links=no}}), was [[King of Portugal]] from 1325 until his death. He was the only legitimate son of King [[Denis of Portugal]] by his wife [[Elizabeth of Aragon]].

sections.title: Early life
sections.paragraphs:
Afonso, born in [[Lisbon]], was the rightful heir to the Portuguese throne. However, he was not Denis' favourite son, the old king preferring his illegitimate son, [[Afonso Sanches, Lord of Albuquerque|Afonso Sanches]].<ref name="Pero-Sanz2011">{{cite book|author=José Miguel Pero-Sanz|title=Santa Isabel: Reina de Portugal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XYIm9o4qHAEC&pg=PA69|date=19 September 2011|publisher=Palabra|isbn=978-84-9840-546-0|page=69}}</ref> The notorious rivalry between the half brothers led to civil war several times. On  7 January 1325, Afonso's father died and he, Afonso IV, became king, whereupon he exiled his rival, Afonso Sanches, to [[Crown of Castile|Castile]], and stripped him of all the lands and [[fiefdom]] given by their father, Denis. From Castile, Afonso Sanches orchestrated a series of attempts to usurp the crown. After a few failed attempts at invasion, the brothers signed a peace treaty, arranged by Afonso's mother Queen [[Elizabeth of Aragon|Elizabeth]].<ref name=Adam>[https://books.google.com/books?id=NdgCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA560 ''Spain and Portugal'', Graeme Mercer Adam ed., J. D. Morris, 1906]</ref>

In 1309, Afonso IV married Infanta [[Beatrice of Castile (1293–1359)|Beatrice of Castile]], daughter of King [[Sancho IV of Castile]] by his wife [[María de Molina]]. The first-born of this union was Infanta [[Maria of Portugal, Queen of Castile|Maria of Portugal]].

sections.title: King of Portugal and Algarve
sections.paragraphs:
In 1325 [[Alfonso XI of Castile]] entered a child-marriage with [[Constanza Manuel]] of Castile, the daughter of one of his regents. Two years later, he had the marriage annulled so he could marry Afonso's daughter, Maria of Portugal. Maria became Queen of Castile in 1328 upon her marriage to Alfonso XI, who soon became involved publicly with a mistress.<ref name=Adam/> Constanza was imprisoned in a castle in Toro while her father, [[Juan Manuel, Prince of Villena]], waged war against Alfonso XI until 1329. Eventually, the two reached a peaceful accord after mediation by Juan del Campo, Bishop of Oviedo; this secured Constance's release from prison.

The public humiliation of his daughter led Afonso IV to have his son and heir, [[Peter I of Portugal|Peter]], marry the no less aggrieved Castilian infanta, Constanza. Afonso subsequently started a war against Castile,<ref name=Adam/> peace arriving four years later, through the intervention of the Infanta Maria herself. A year after the peace treaty was signed in [[Seville]], Portuguese troops played an important role in defeating the [[Moors]] at the [[Battle of Río Salado]] in October 1340.

sections.title: Later life
sections.paragraphs:
[[Image:Inès de Castro se jetant avec ses enfants aux pieds d'Alphonse IV roi.jpg|left|300px|thumb|Inês on her knees in front of King Afonso]]
Political intrigue marked the last part of Afonso IV's reign, although Castille was torn by civil war after Alfonso XI died. [[Henry of Trastámara]] challenged the new King [[Peter of Castile]], who sent many Castilian nobles into exile in Portugal. Afonso's heir, [[Peter I of Portugal|Pedro]], fell in love with his new wife's lady-in-waiting, [[Inês de Castro]]. Inês was the daughter of an important noble family from [[Kingdom of Galicia|Galicia]], with links (albeit illegitimate) to both the royal houses of Castile and Portugal. Her brothers were aligned with the Trastamara faction, and became favorites of crown prince Pedro, much to the dismay of others at the Portuguese court, who considered them Castilian upstarts. When [[Constance of Peñafiel]] died weeks after giving birth to their third child, Pedro began living openly with Inês, recognized all her children as his and repudiated the idea of marrying anyone other than Inês herself. His father refused to go to war again against Castile, hoping his heir's infatuation would end, and tried to arrange another dynastic marriage for Pedro.

The situation became worse as the years passed and the aging Afonso lost control over his court. His grandson and Pedro's only legitimate son, future king [[Ferdinand I of Portugal|Fernando of Portugal]], was a sickly child, while Inês' illegitimate children thrived. Worried about his legitimate grandson's life, and the growing power of Castile within Portugal's borders, Afonso ordered Inês de Castro first imprisoned in his mother's old convent in [[Coimbra]], and then murdered in 1355. He expected his son to give in and marry a princess, but the heir became enraged upon learning of his lover's decapitation in front of their young children. Pedro put himself at the head of an army and devastated the country between the [[Douro]] and the [[Minho River|Minho]] rivers before he was reconciled to his father in early 1357.<ref>{{EB1911|inline=1|wstitle=Alphonso|display=Alphonso s.v. Alphonso IV.|first=David|last=Hannay|authorlink=David Hannay (historian)|volume=1|page=733}}</ref> Afonso died almost immediately after, in Lisbon in May.

Afonso IV's nickname ''the Brave'' alludes to his martial exploits. However, his most important accomplishments were the relative peace enjoyed by the country during his long reign and the support he gave to the [[Portuguese Navy]]. Afonso granted public funding to raise a proper commercial fleet and ordered the first Portuguese maritime explorations. The conflict with Pedro, and the explorations he initiated, eventually became the foundation of the Portuguese national epic, ''[[Os Lusíadas]]'' by [[Luís de Camões]].

The dramatic circumstances of the relationship between father and son and Inês de Castro was used as the basis for the plot of more than twenty operas and ballets. The story with its tragic denouement is immortalized in several plays and poems in Portuguese, such as ''[[Os Lusíadas|The Lusíadas]]'' by [[Luís de Camões]] (canto iii, stanzas 118-135), and in Spanish, including ''Nise lastimosa'' and ''Nise laureada'' (1577) by [[Jerónimo Bermúdez]], ''Reinar despues de morir'' by [[Luís Vélez de Guevara]], as well as a play by French playwright [[Henry de Montherlant]] called ''La Reine morte'' (''The Dead Queen''). [[Mary Russell Mitford]] also wrote a drama based on the story entitled ''Inez de Castro''. ''Inês de Castro'' is a novel by [[Maria Pilar Queralt del Hierro]] in Spanish and Portuguese.

sections.title: Marriage and descendants

values.value: "We assume that after the marriage of dona Beatriz and don Alfonso IV, married life was harmonious (...) based on the fact that D. Afonso IV did not have any bastard children, thereby breaking a long family tradition" (loose translation){{Sfn|Lourenço Menino|2008|p=356}}
"Perhaps since he had so many problems with those of his father, D. Afonso did not have any illegitimate children." (loose translation){{Sfn|Sotto Mayor Pizarro|1997|p=201}}

"There are no known bastard children of the king. Two possible explanations could be the ties of profound esteem, friendship and respect that existed because he had been raised and had lived from a very early age with his future wife or, perhaps, because he wanted to avoid that his heirs had the same problems that he had had with his bastard brothers".(loose translation){{Sfn|Rodrigues Oliveira|2010|p=217}}
